basics.name: Patrick Alexander Walkden
basics.label: Postdoctoral Researcher
basics.summary: Researcher specialising in modelling the impacts of anthropogenic pressures on biodiversity and its contributions to people

work.name: Natural History Museum, Biodiversity Futures Lab
work.summary: Working on a large-scale and multi-institutional project assessing the biodiversity modelling tools to support the Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework including reviewing the current modelling landscape as well as predicting biodiversity responses under different future scenarios.

education.institution: Imperial College London & Natural History Museum
education.area: Thesis: The functional implications of land use and climate change on bird assmeblages worldwide

awards.title: Global Fellows Fund grant
awards.summary: The Global Fellows Fund supports high impact international placements for PhD students in labs at Imperial's strategic international partners. I undertook a 3-month placement at Cornell Univeristy, New York, USA

publications.name: The scale of human impacts on ecosystem integrity revealed by avian functional traits
publications.summary: The output of the first data chapter of my PhD. This work develops novel approaches of measuring ecosystem integrity using fine-resolution avian functional traits. We demonstrate the power of these approaches by revealing the deterioration on ecosystem integrity in increasingly human modified habitats.

publications.name: The functional integrity of bird communities worldwide
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Functional traits mediate sensitivity to local pressure in North American birds
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
